ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to interact with individuals with Autism.
a great class! all about ASD

This class teaches all the basic knowledge about autism and related disorders. We also got to hear the perspective from people with autism themselves, which was really insightful. You also volunteer with autistic people which is such an amazing and eye opening experience.
I learned a lot about different aspects of ASD & related disorders  symptoms, treatment, family, etc. It was also great to do a field placement.
Symptomology, development, challenges, diagnosis, and treatment of autism and asperger's. Many perspectives, primarily researchers but also family members and individuals with autism

I gained lots of insight into the services that are provided for children with ASD through the volunteer work. The lectures were informative in explaining the deep issues that people on the spectrum face today.
Learnt more about different aspects of ASD and perspectives from different lecturers.
General overview of many facets of autism, including perspectives from parents, doctors, siblings, teachers, and individuals with ASD themselves.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor is great. The requirement to volunteer outside of class time was amazing. Also that the class only met once a week for an hour and a half was amazing.

Engaging and interesting class that gives a good perspective on up to date autism research and intervention, and gives students hands on experience working with kids with autism. Prof still uses some outdated terminology, though, and the course lacks organization and good communication
Weaknesses was not a lot of communication with students on assignments and expectations. It was a bit hard to navigate at times.
nothing- an awesome course that went above and beyond with so many guest lecturers

Strengths - field placements; allowed to pick what interests you for a final paper 
Weaknesses - sometimes due dates were unclear / paper guidelines

Strengths: excellent range of guest speakers, minimal amount of readings, very open to class questions

Weaknesses: Unclear assignment details

Improvements: Perhaps more on the neurodiversity movement/debate, more perspectives from individuals with ASD on how they would prefer we address their condition and what changes they want to see
I feel it could be improved by organizing the canvas page, but other than that the format was good.
There was minimal engagement (just a powerpoint lecture) and the lessons didn't connect well.
Enjoyed the structure of the course and the different guest speakers.

Dr. Volkmar is incredible. This class very quickly became my favorite class ever taken at Yale and beyond. He is a genius and has made significant strides in this field of research. He is humble, kind, passionate about the topic, and engaging. I am really going to miss this class, and I am so sad I won't be able to take another class from Dr. Volkmar. Well deserved retirement for him, though! I know he will still continue on to do more incredible things.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes 100% especially if you are interested in developmental psychology.
YES
yes
Yes - especially the field placement offers a unique opportunity to learn in a new way & apply what you learn in class

Yes. Good overview of ASD that starts from foundations and then goes into many different detailed avenues from a biological and social level. You can do as much or as little work for the course as you want according to your level of engagement with the topic. Guest speakers who you would likely not encounter otherwise.

Yes I would because I believe this course provides a thorough introduction to a condition that is very prevalent in our society today. It is a quickly growing area of research where new findings are being discovered frequently.
The practicum component is valuable, but the actual lectures are not.
Yes! It was a really engaging and interesting class.
100%. Best class I've ever taken.
It is far too easy.
